title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: As they'd walked up Marlborough Street he had a similar pounding of hope, checking all the cars. But no black Volkswagen Golf.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Instead of turning up Marlborough Street they kept walking along the prom to Porty Baths, a Victorian sandstone building with balconies out front and a huge glass roof.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He reached the bottom of Marlborough Street and turned to the sea. The vastness of it normally helped Mark get perspective on the stupid little worries of everyday life.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Five minutes to park and get Nathan. He turned down Bath Street rather than Marlborough Street to save time, then met a Tesco van coming the other way and had to pull in. Come on, for Christ's sake.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Mark and Nathan struggled round the bandstand and up Marlborough Street, past the detached houses to the flats at the top. Number 12, red door.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He got to the bottom of the street, no spaces. Into Straiton Place, eventually he found a place almost at Marlborough Street. Locked up and scuttled along the prom in a half-jog.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He turned and headed up Marlborough Street.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: The wind was hurtling up Marlborough Street from the sea, bustling the Lexus. Taylor killed the engine and slumped back into his seat holding his shoulder.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He ran until his chest burned and his legs turned to liquid and all he could hear was his own heartbeat thundering in his head, until it felt like all the blood in his body would burst out his veins at once. He ran past the bottom of Marlborough Street and on, feet slapping on the prom, past the swimming baths and the flats.

title: Gone Again
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Ferguson pointed towards Marlborough Street. 'He's got Mr Taylor.'
